canonical_explanation.text: Two figures are congruent if they have the same shape and size. Two triangles are congruent if their corresponding sides and corresponding angles are equal. We do not need to verify all six elements; specific criteria suffice: SSS (three sides), SAS (two sides and the included angle), ASA (two angles and the included side), AAS (two angles and a non-included side), and RHS (right angle, hypotenuse, and one side).
rules: SSS: If three sides of one triangle equal three sides of another, the triangles are congruent
SAS: If two sides and the included angle of one triangle equal those of another, the triangles are congruent
ASA: If two angles and the included side of one triangle equal those of another, the triangles are congruent
AAS: If two angles and a non-included side of one triangle equal those of another, the triangles are congruent
RHS: If the hypotenuse and one side of a right triangle equal those of another right triangle, the triangles are congruent
Congruent triangles are written with corresponding vertices in order: triangle ABC is congruent to triangle DEF

questions.question_text: Two figures are congruent if they have:
questions.explanation_correct: Congruent figures have both the same shape and the same size.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Congruence means identical shape AND size.

questions.question_text: Two circles with the same radius are congruent.
questions.explanation_correct: Circles with equal radii have the same shape and size, so they are congruent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same radius means same size and shape. They are congruent.

questions.question_text: If triangle ABC is congruent to triangle DEF, which side corresponds to AB?
questions.explanation_correct: In the congruence ABC ≅ DEF, the order matters: A↔D, B↔E, C↔F. So AB↔DE.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Corresponding vertices in order: A↔D, B↔E. So AB↔DE.

questions.question_text: If triangle PQR is congruent to triangle XYZ, which angle corresponds to angle Q?
questions.explanation_correct: PQR ≅ XYZ: P↔X, Q↔Y, R↔Z. So angle Q corresponds to angle Y.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In PQR ≅ XYZ, Q↔Y.

questions.question_text: If triangle ABC ≅ triangle PQR, then BC = ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A↔P, B↔Q, C↔R. So BC corresponds to QR.
questions.explanation_incorrect: B↔Q, C↔R. So BC = QR.

questions.question_text: Which criterion is used when all three sides of two triangles are equal?
questions.explanation_correct: When all three sides are equal, we use the SSS (Side-Side-Side) criterion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Three sides equal = SSS criterion.

questions.question_text: In SAS congruence, the angle must be:

options.text: The included angle between the two sides

questions.explanation_correct: In SAS, the angle must be the included angle (the angle between the two given sides).
questions.explanation_incorrect: SAS requires the angle to be between (included by) the two sides.

questions.question_text: Which congruence criterion involves two angles and the included side?
questions.explanation_correct: ASA (Angle-Side-Angle) uses two angles and the side between them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two angles and the included side = ASA criterion.

questions.question_text: RHS congruence applies only to:
questions.explanation_correct: RHS (Right angle-Hypotenuse-Side) can only be applied to right-angled triangles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: RHS requires a right angle, so it only applies to right-angled triangles.

questions.question_text: SSA (two sides and a non-included angle) is a valid congruence criterion.
questions.explanation_correct: SSA is not a valid congruence criterion because it can produce two different triangles (ambiguous case).
questions.explanation_incorrect: SSA does not guarantee congruence. It is the ambiguous case.

questions.question_text: Two triangles have sides 5 cm, 7 cm, 9 cm and 5 cm, 7 cm, 9 cm respectively. By which criterion are they congruent?
questions.explanation_correct: All three corresponding sides are equal, so the criterion is SSS.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Three pairs of equal sides = SSS.

questions.question_text: In triangles ABC and DEF: AB = DE, angle B = angle E, BC = EF. The congruence criterion is:
questions.explanation_correct: Two sides (AB=DE, BC=EF) and the included angle (B=E) are equal. This is SAS.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two sides and the included angle = SAS.

questions.question_text: In triangles PQR and XYZ: angle P = angle X, PQ = XY, angle Q = angle Y. The criterion is:
questions.explanation_correct: Two angles (P=X, Q=Y) and the included side (PQ=XY) are equal. This is ASA.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two angles and the included side = ASA.

questions.question_text: In triangles ABC and DEF: angle A = angle D = 90 degrees, AB = DE = 3 cm, BC = EF = 5 cm. The triangles are congruent by:
questions.explanation_correct: Both are right-angled, hypotenuse BC=EF and one side AB=DE. This is RHS.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Right angle + hypotenuse + one side = RHS.

questions.question_text: If triangle ABC ≅ triangle DEF by SAS, and AB = 4 cm, BC = 6 cm, angle B = 50 degrees, what is angle E?
questions.explanation_correct: Angle B corresponds to angle E. Since the triangles are congruent, angle E = angle B = 50 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Corresponding angles are equal: angle E = angle B = 50 degrees.

questions.question_text: If triangle ABC ≅ triangle DEF, and AC = 8 cm, then DF = ___ cm.
questions.explanation_correct: A↔D, C↔F. So AC corresponds to DF. DF = AC = 8 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AC ↔ DF = 8 cm.

questions.question_text: Two triangles have: angle A = angle D, angle B = angle E, AB = DE. The congruence criterion is:
questions.explanation_correct: Angle A=D, angle B=E, and the included side AB=DE. This is ASA.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two angles and the side between them = ASA.

questions.question_text: Two triangles have: angle A = angle D, angle C = angle F, BC = EF. The congruence criterion is:
questions.explanation_correct: Two angles (A=D, C=F) and a non-included side (BC=EF). This is AAS.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two angles and a non-included side = AAS.

questions.question_text: How many elements (sides and angles) does a triangle have?
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle has 3 sides and 3 angles = 6 elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3 sides + 3 angles = 6 elements.

questions.question_text: In triangle ABC and DEF: AB = DE, BC = EF, AC = DF. Which statement is correct?
questions.explanation_correct: AB=DE, BC=EF, AC=DF means A↔D, B↔E, C↔F. So ABC ≅ DEF by SSS.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Matching sides in order: ABC ≅ DEF.

questions.question_text: How many minimum measurements are needed to check congruence of two triangles?
questions.explanation_correct: We need at least 3 measurements (as in SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS, or RHS) to establish congruence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All congruence criteria require exactly 3 measurements.

questions.question_text: In the figure, ABCD is a rectangle. Triangles ABD and ACD are:
questions.explanation_correct: Both are right triangles (rectangle corners), AD is common (hypotenuse = diagonal), AB = CD (opposite sides). By RHS, they are congruent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Right angle + same diagonal (hypotenuse) + equal sides = RHS congruence.

questions.question_text: All squares of side 5 cm are congruent to each other.
questions.explanation_correct: Squares with the same side length have the same shape (all angles 90 degrees) and same size. They are congruent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same side length = same shape and size = congruent.

questions.question_text: In triangles ABC and PQR, AB = PQ = 5 cm, angle A = angle P = 60 degrees, AC = PR = 7 cm. By which criterion are they congruent?
questions.explanation_correct: AB=PQ, angle A=angle P (included angle), AC=PR. This is SAS.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two sides and the included angle = SAS.

questions.question_text: Triangle ABC ≅ triangle PQR. If angle A = 80 degrees and angle B = 60 degrees, find angle R.
questions.explanation_correct: Angle C = 180 - 80 - 60 = 40 degrees. C↔R, so angle R = 40 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: C = 40 degrees. Since C↔R, angle R = 40 degrees.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a valid congruence criterion?
questions.explanation_correct: AAA (three angles equal) means similar triangles, not necessarily congruent. Triangles can have the same angles but different sizes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AAA gives similar triangles, not congruent ones.

questions.question_text: In right triangles ABC and DEF (right angle at B and E), AC = DF = 10 cm, AB = DE = 6 cm. Are they congruent?
questions.explanation_correct: Right angle (B=E), hypotenuse (AC=DF), one side (AB=DE). RHS criterion is satisfied.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Right angle + hypotenuse + side = RHS. Yes, congruent.

questions.question_text: Two line segments are congruent if they have:
questions.explanation_correct: Two line segments are congruent if they have the same length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Congruent line segments = equal lengths.

questions.question_text: The congruence criterion that requires a right angle, hypotenuse, and one side is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: RHS stands for Right angle-Hypotenuse-Side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Right angle + Hypotenuse + Side = RHS.

questions.question_text: ABCD is a square. Diagonal AC divides it into triangles ABC and ACD. These triangles are congruent by:
questions.explanation_correct: AB=CD, BC=AD, AC=AC (SSS). Also AB=CD, angle ABC=angle CDA=90, BC=AD (SAS). Both work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both SSS and SAS can be used.

questions.question_text: Two congruent triangles have:
questions.explanation_correct: Congruent triangles have equal sides and angles, so they have equal perimeters and equal areas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same shape and size means same perimeter and same area.

questions.question_text: In triangles ABC and XYZ: AB = XY = 4 cm, angle A = angle X = 50 degrees, angle B = angle Y = 70 degrees. Criterion:
questions.explanation_correct: Angle A = X, side AB = XY (included side), angle B = Y. This is ASA.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two angles + included side = ASA.

questions.question_text: If triangle ABC ≅ triangle DEF and perimeter of ABC = 24 cm, then perimeter of DEF is:
questions.explanation_correct: Congruent triangles have equal corresponding sides, so their perimeters are equal. Perimeter of DEF = 24 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Congruent triangles have equal perimeters: 24 cm.

questions.question_text: Two angles are congruent if they have:
questions.explanation_correct: Two angles are congruent if and only if they have the same measure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Congruent angles = equal measure.

questions.question_text: If two triangles have all three angles equal (AAA), they are always congruent.
questions.explanation_correct: AAA means similar, not congruent. Two triangles can have the same angles but different side lengths.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AAA gives similar triangles. They could be different sizes.

questions.question_text: In the figure, AB = CD and AD = BC. Triangle ABD ≅ Triangle CDB by:
questions.explanation_correct: AB=CD, AD=BC, BD=BD (common side). Three sides equal = SSS.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AB=CD, AD=BC, BD=BD (common). SSS criterion.

questions.question_text: In an isosceles triangle ABC with AB = AC, a median BM is drawn to side AC. Triangles ABM and remainder:

options.text: Are congruent only if M is the midpoint of AC

questions.explanation_correct: If BM is a median, M is the midpoint of AC. Then AM = MC, BM = BM (common), AB may or may not equal BC. For a full analysis, we need specific measurements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A median goes to the midpoint, making the two parts of the base equal.

questions.question_text: In SAS criterion, the 'S' stands for:
questions.explanation_correct: In SAS, S stands for Side and A stands for Angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: SAS = Side-Angle-Side.

questions.question_text: Two right triangles have hypotenuse 13 cm each and one leg 5 cm each. The other leg of each is:
questions.explanation_correct: Other leg = sqrt(13^2 - 5^2) = sqrt(169-25) = sqrt(144) = 12 cm.

questions.question_text: If triangle ABC ≅ triangle PQR, then:

options.text: AB = PQ, BC = QR, CA = RP
AB = QR, BC = RP, CA = PQ
AB = RP, BC = PQ, CA = QR
AB = PQ, BC = RP, CA = QR

questions.explanation_correct: A↔P, B↔Q, C↔R. So AB=PQ, BC=QR, CA=RP.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Match in order: AB=PQ, BC=QR, CA=RP.

questions.question_text: Which congruence criterion uses two sides and the angle between them?
questions.explanation_correct: SAS: two sides and the included (between) angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two sides + included angle = SAS.

questions.question_text: If triangle LMN ≅ triangle XYZ by ASA, and angle L = 45 degrees, LM = 6 cm, angle M = 75 degrees, then angle Y = ___ degrees.
questions.explanation_correct: L↔X, M↔Y. So angle Y = angle M = 75 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: M↔Y. Angle Y = 75 degrees.

questions.question_text: How many pairs of congruent triangles are formed by the diagonals of a rectangle?
questions.explanation_correct: The diagonals create 4 triangles. Opposite triangles are congruent, giving 2 pairs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diagonals of a rectangle create 4 triangles forming 2 congruent pairs.

questions.question_text: In triangles ABC and DEF: angle B = angle E = 90 degrees, AC = DF (hypotenuse), angle A = angle D. The criterion is:
questions.explanation_correct: We have right angle (B=E=90), hypotenuse (AC=DF), and angle A=D. This satisfies both AAS (angle A, angle B, side AC) and RHS (right angle, hypotenuse, and since angle A=D, the sides opposite these angles are also equal by Pythagoras).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both AAS and RHS criteria are satisfied.

questions.question_text: Triangle ABC has AB = 5, BC = 6, AC = 7. Triangle DEF has DE = 5, EF = 6, DF = 7. If ABC ≅ DEF, angle A = 57 degrees, find angle D.
questions.explanation_correct: A↔D (corresponding vertices). Angle D = angle A = 57 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Corresponding angles are equal: angle D = 57 degrees.

questions.question_text: The symbol for congruence is:
questions.explanation_correct: The symbol ≅ denotes congruence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ≅ is the congruence symbol.

questions.question_text: If two triangles are congruent, their areas are equal.
questions.explanation_correct: Congruent triangles have the same side lengths and angles, so their areas must be equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Congruent means same shape and size, so same area.

questions.question_text: For RHS congruence, which three elements must match?

options.text: Right angle, hypotenuse, and one leg

questions.explanation_correct: RHS requires: a right angle, equal hypotenuses, and one pair of equal legs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: RHS = Right angle + Hypotenuse + one Side (leg).

questions.question_text: In an equilateral triangle ABC, a line from A to midpoint M of BC creates two triangles. They are congruent by:
questions.explanation_correct: AB=AC, BM=MC, AM=AM (SSS). Also AB=AC, angle ABM=angle ACM, BM=MC (SAS). AM is also altitude so angle AMB=90, making RHS work too.
questions.explanation_incorrect: SSS, SAS, and RHS all apply in this case.

questions.question_text: If triangle ABC ≅ triangle DEF, AB = 3 cm, BC = 4 cm, CA = 5 cm. The perimeter of triangle DEF is:
questions.explanation_correct: Congruent triangles have equal corresponding sides. Perimeter = 3 + 4 + 5 = 12 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: DE=3, EF=4, FD=5. Perimeter = 12 cm.
